them around Fitzroy Crossing

3270.text:
and I was like
'What are these?

3271.text:
I've never seen these
before.' So it turned out

3274.text:
all the ones in Kununurra
weren't trachyderma.

3277.text:
The old records - because
we never really found them -

3280.text:
they turned out to be other
species and this guy turned

3286.text:
out to be a new
kind of species.

3297.text:
So he's - he's in
the 'click'-er camp

3299.text:
but you can see he's added a
few pulses, so it's starting

3302.text:
to be a mini rasp,
if that makes sense.

3308.text:
Okay - and I'll
leave you with that.

3311.text:
So I'd just like to thank
all the frogtographers

3317.text:
This is Marion Anstis
here, tadpole lady.

3323.text:
This is Scotty from one of
our trips last year, a cool

3326.text:
Aboriginal kid from
Kalumburu and that's Claire

3329.text:
who used to be from
the Museum and Mitzy.

3333.text:
When we got that sinkhole, she
was there to discover that too.

3339.text:
Alcoa's sponsored us for a
long time and other projects

3342.text:
at the Museum as well
including the education team.

3350.text:
Wildlife or CALM or DEC -
often I work with those guys

3356.text:
because it's really good to
get out together and lots of

3363.text:
I like a bit of - usually on
the trips I try to mix it up

3366.text:
with a bit of youth, a bit
of wisdom, ie old people

3370.text:
and, you know, mix it up a
bit, so you get different

3375.text:
teams and a different
experience and everyone's

3376.text:
worked really hard on the
trips to get the pictures

3381.text:
So thanks to all
those people. The End.
